unit: Unit 7 | Inference for Quantitative Data: Means
title: Interpreting a Confidence Interval
question_text:
A $90\%$ confidence interval for an unknown population mean, $\mu$, has been calculated as $87±12$.
What is the correct interpretation of this confidence interval?

choices.text: We are $90\%$ confident that the unknown population mean is between $75$ and $99$.
There is a $0.9$ probability that the unknown population mean is between $75$ and $99$.
$90\%$ of all confidence intervals will be between $75$ and $99$.
If we took many samples from this population, $90\%$ of the computed confidence intervals would contain the unknown population mean.
$90\%$ of data from the population is between $75$ and $99$.

solution:
For a particular confidence interval, we have a stated level (in this case, $90\%$) of confidence concerning the value of the unknown population mean.

Explanation of Distractors

Choice 'B' is incorrect; the interval either does or does not contain the true value of the unknown population mean, $µ$. Therefore, one cannot give a probability interpretation of the confidence interval.

Choice 'C' is incorrect; one cannot generalize results to other confidence intervals based on this one.

Choice 'D' is incorrect; this is a correct interpretation of a confidence level (i.e., all $90\%$ confidence intervals), but it is not a correct interpretation of a particular confidence interval such as the one in this question.

Choice 'E' is incorrect; confidence intervals hope to establish a range of values that capture the unknown population mean in repeated samples. Confidence intervals do not describe the proportion of data within a certain interval.
